options.help:
Embed interactive forms to collect information from your visitors. Great for:

  • Contact forms
  • Newsletter signups
  • Event registrations
  • Feedback collection
  • Lead generation

When adding a form:

  • Choose from your pre-configured form templates
  • Add a clear headline explaining the form's purpose
  • Consider adding a tagline with extra context or instructions
  • Ensure all required fields are clearly marked

You can create or edit forms outside of this block in the Forms collection.

Create visual showcases with multiple images. Ideal for:

  • Product portfolios
  • Project showcases
  • Event photo collections
  • Team member galleries
  • Before/after demonstrations

Tips for great galleries:

  • Use consistently sized images for the best presentation
  • Add descriptive headlines to provide context
  • Consider a tagline to explain what visitors are seeing
  • Organize images in a logical sequence

options.help:
Creates a prominent section at the top of your page that immediately captures attention. Ideal for:

  • Main page headers with impactful headlines
  • Showcasing key messages with supporting text
  • Featuring high-quality images that support your message
  • Adding clear call-to-action buttons

Tips for effective heroes:

  • Keep headlines clear and concise (recommended 2-8 words)
  • Use high-resolution images that work well with overlay text
  • Consider image placement (left/center/right) based on your headline length
  • Add a succinct tagline to provide additional context

options.help:
Automatically displays your most recent blog posts in chronological order. Perfect for:

  • Showing latest articles on your homepage
  • Keeping your content fresh and up-to-date
  • Creating dynamic content sections
  • Showcasing your recent writing

You can:

  • Set the number of posts to display
  • Add a custom headline and tagline to label the section
  • Trust the system to automatically keep your content current

The posts will automatically update as you publish new content, ensuring your pages always show your latest articles.

options.help:
Display your product or service pricing options in a clear, comparative format. Use this when:

  • Showcasing different service tiers
  • Highlighting feature differences between plans
  • Promoting special offers or featured plans
  • Presenting subscription options

Best practices:

  • Use clear, benefit-focused plan names
  • Highlight your recommended or most popular option
  • Keep feature lists scannable and easy to compare
  • Include clear call-to-action buttons for each plan

options.text: Form submissions are configured to be read-only for data integrity reasons. But they are a great candidate for use in [Flows](/admin/settings/flows). Directus Flows is a drag and drop, low-code automation builder to simplify tasks like automatic notifications or sending incoming requests to third party services. Learn more about Flows.

options.help:
Form Submissions

Form submissions are read-only records of responses received through your site's forms. This ensures data integrity and provides a reliable audit trail of all submitted information.

Understanding Submissions

Each submission contains:

  • Unique submission ID
  • Timestamp of submission
  • Reference to the parent form
  • All submitted field values

Automating with Flows

While submissions are read-only, you can use Flows to automate actions when new submissions arrive:

  • Send custom email notifications
  • Push data to external services
  • Create records in other collections
  • Trigger webhooks
  • Format and transform submission data

Think of Flows as your automation toolkit - they let you act on submission data without modifying the original records.

Data Management

Exporting Data

Export submissions to work with them outside the CMS:

  • Download as CSV for spreadsheet analysis
  • Include date ranges for periodic reports
  • Select specific fields to include
  • Export file attachments in bulk

Data Cleanup

Keep your submission data organized:

  • Archive old submissions
  • Monitor storage usage from file uploads
  • Watch for spam patterns
  • Maintain audit logs

Privacy & Security

Since form submissions often contain personal data:

  • Follow your data retention policy
  • Handle personal information according to privacy laws
  • Regularly review old submissions for deletion
  • Consider automation for data cleanup
  • Monitor who has access to submission data

options.help:
Understanding Forms

Forms are reusable components that you create once and can place anywhere on your site using Form blocks. Think of the Forms collection as your form template library - you build the forms here, then use Form blocks to display them on your pages.

The Forms & Form Blocks Relationship

  1. First, create and configure your form in the Forms collection
  2. Then, add a Form block to any page where you want the form to appear
  3. Select your form from the dropdown in the Form block settings
  4. Customize the block's headline and tagline to match your page context

This approach lets you:

  • Reuse the same form across multiple pages
  • Update the form once to change it everywhere
  • Maintain consistent data collection
  • Track submissions from all instances of the form

Creating Forms

Basic Settings

Form Title

Internal name to identify your form in the admin panel. Choose something descriptive like:

  • "Newsletter Signup 2024"
  • "Contact Form - Main"
  • "Event Registration Form"

Submit Button

Customize the text on your submit button. Use action-oriented phrases like:

  • "Send Message"
  • "Sign Up Now"
  • "Register Today"

Success Handling

Choose what happens after submission:

Show Message

  • Display a custom thank you message
  • Confirm the submission was received
  • Set expectations for next steps

Redirect

  • Send users to a specific thank you page
  • Guide them to relevant content
  • Start the next step in their journey

Email Notifications

Configure automated emails for form submissions:

  • Add multiple recipient email addresses
  • Customize subject lines and messages
  • Include form submission details in the email

Active Status

Control form availability:

  • Enable/disable without deleting
  • Temporarily pause data collection
  • Test before making public

Building Your Form

Available Field Types

  • Text: Single line text input
  • Textarea: Multi-line text input
  • Checkbox: Single yes/no option
  • Checkbox Group: Multiple selectable options
  • Radio: Single choice from options
  • Select: Dropdown menu
  • File: File upload capability
  • Hidden: Invisible fields for tracking

Field Configuration

Label The visible field name shown to users

Placeholder Optional hint text inside empty fields

Help Text Additional instructions below the field

Required Fields Mark essential fields that must be filled out

Width Options Control field layout:

  • Full width (100%)
  • Two-thirds (67%)
  • Half (50%)
  • One-third (33%)

Validation: Here's the available rules

  • Email format: email
  • URL format: url
  • Minimum length: min:5 (replace 5 with desired length)
  • Maximum length: max:20 (replace 20 with desired length)
  • Exact length: length:10 (replace 10 with desired length)
  • Required fields: Set "Required" toggle to true

You can combine rules with pipes: email|max:255

Using Forms with Form Blocks

Adding Forms to Pages

  1. Add a Form block to your page
  2. Select your form from the dropdown
  3. Add an optional headline and tagline
  4. Preview to check the layout

Form Block Customization

  • Add context with a headline
  • Provide instructions in the tagline
  • Match the form to your page content
  • Ensure the form fits your layout

Best Practices

Form Design & Experience

  • Keep forms as short as possible - only include essential fields
  • Group related fields together logically
  • Use clear labels and mark required fields
  • Ensure error messages are helpful and specific
  • Test on both desktop and mobile devices

Data Collection

  • Only collect information you'll actually use
  • Follow data protection guidelines
  • Review submissions regularly

Managing Form Submissions

All submissions are stored in the Form Submissions collection.

  • Export data as needed
  • Configure email notifications
  • Track submission sources
  • Monitor submission trends

options.help:
Global Settings

These settings control site-wide elements that affect your entire website. There's only one global settings record.

Site Info

  • Title: Your website's name, appears in browser tabs and search results
  • Tagline: Short description of your site used in search results
  • Description: Longer site summary for SEO and social sharing
  • Website URL: Your site's public address
  • CMS URL: Address of your admin system

Brand Assets

  • Logo: Main site logo for light backgrounds
  • Dark Mode Logo: Alternate logo for dark themes
  • Favicon: Small icon for browser tabs (max 512×512px)
  • Accent Color: Your brand's primary color for buttons and highlights

Social Media Links

Add URLs for your social profiles:

  • Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn
  • Twitter, YouTube, Vimeo
  • GitHub, Discord, Docker

API Settings

  • OpenAI API Key: Required for AI-powered features

What is the name of this menu? Only used internally.

Show or hide this menu from the site.

options.text: Create and manage navigation menus for your website. Each menu can contain multiple links organized into a hierarchy.

options.help:
Understanding Navigation

Navigation menus help visitors find their way around your site. You can create multiple menus (like main navigation, footer links, or utility menus) and manage them all from this collection.

Navigation Structure

Each navigation menu consists of:

  1. A menu container (Navigation)
  2. Menu items within it (Navigation Items)

Creating Navigation Menus

Menu Settings

Title

Internal name for your menu (only visible in admin). Examples:

  • "Main Navigation"
  • "Footer Links"
  • "Header Utility Menu"

Active Status

Toggle menus on/off without deleting them. Useful for:

  • Testing new menu structures
  • Seasonal navigation changes
  • Temporary menu updates

Adding Menu Items

Item Types

Page

  • Link to any page in your site
  • Automatically updates if page URL changes
  • Maintains internal link structure

Post

  • Link to a specific blog post
  • Useful for featuring important articles
  • Updates automatically if post URL changes

URL

  • Link to any external website (e.g., "https://example.com")
  • Create social media links
  • Link to specific file downloads
  • Add internal anchor links (e.g., "#contact-section")
  • Point to email addresses (e.g., "mailto:contact@example.com")
  • Link to phone numbers (e.g., "tel:+1234567890")

Group

  • Creates a container for other menu items
  • Appears as a dropdown menu when hovered
  • Can contain any mix of Pages, Posts, URLs, or other Groups
  • Perfect for organizing related content (e.g., "Services", "Products")
  • Can be nested to create multi-level navigation
  • Doesn't require a URL - acts as a category header

Examples of Group Usage:

About (Group) 
└─ Our Story (Page)
└─ Team (Page)
└─ Careers (URL - External job board)

Services (Group) 
└─ Consulting (Page) 
└─ Training (Group) 
└─ Online Courses (URL) 
└─ Workshops (Page) 
└─ Support (Page)

Item Settings

Title

The text shown to visitors in the menu

Parent Item

For creating nested navigation:

  • Select another item as parent
  • Creates dropdown menus
  • Builds hierarchical structure

Sort Order

Control the sequence of menu items:

  • Drag and drop to reorder
  • Items display in ascending order
  • Groups show as dropdowns

Best Practices

Structure

  • Keep main navigation simple
  • Limit dropdown levels to 2-3
  • Group related items logically
  • Use clear, concise labels

Usability

  • Ensure all items are reachable
  • Test on mobile devices
  • Review links regularly
  • Keep labels brief but descriptive

options.text: Build dynamic pages quickly using ready-made blocks. See our documentation to learn more about the Page Builder.

options.help:
Creating and Managing Pages

Pages are the foundation of your website, where you'll combine different content blocks to create engaging layouts. Each page can be built using a mix of blocks like Hero sections, Rich Text, Forms, and more.

Page Settings

Title

The page title appears in browser tabs and search results. Make it clear and descriptive of the page's content. This is what visitors will see when they bookmark your page or share it on social media.

URL (Permalink)

  • Always starts with a forward slash (/)
  • Use simple, lowercase words separated by hyphens
  • Keep it short but descriptive
  • Examples:
    • /about
    • /contact-us
    • /services/web-design

Description

A brief summary of the page that appears in search results. Write 1-2 sentences that clearly explain what visitors will find on this page. Good descriptions help with SEO and encourage people to click through to your site.

Publishing Options

  • Draft: Work on the page without making it public
  • In Review: Submit the page for review by other team members
  • Published: Make the page visible to the public
  • Schedule: Set a future publication date

Working with Blocks

Your page content is built by adding and arranging blocks. Think of blocks as building pieces that you can stack and rearrange to create your perfect page layout.

Tips for Building with Blocks

  • Start with a Hero block for main landing pages
  • Use consistent block types for similar content across pages
  • Consider the natural flow of information when ordering blocks
  • Preview your page on both desktop and mobile before publishing
  • You can temporarily hide blocks without deleting them using the "Hide block" toggle

Block Background Options

Each block can have either a light or dark background:

  • Default (light): Default option, best for regular content sections
  • Dark: Creates visual contrast, good for highlighting important sections

General Tips for All Blocks

  • Preview your changes before publishing
  • Consider mobile viewing experience
  • Keep related content in the same block type for consistency
  • Use clear headlines and taglines to guide your visitors
  • Make sure images are optimized for web use
  • Test all interactive elements like forms and buttons

options.help:
Managing Blog Posts

Blog posts are a powerful way to share your content, news, and updates with your audience. Each post can include rich text content, images, and metadata to help with organization and discovery.

Post Settings

Title

The main headline of your blog post. This appears at the top of the post and in preview cards across your site. Make it:

  • Engaging and descriptive
  • Clear about the post's content
  • Optimized for search engines (aim for 50-60 characters)

Description

A brief preview of your post that appears in blog listings and search results. Write 1-2 compelling sentences that:

  • Summarize the main point of your article
  • Entice readers to click through
  • Include relevant keywords naturally

Featured Image

The main visual for your post that appears:

  • At the top of the post
  • In preview cards across your site
  • When sharing on social media Use high-quality, relevant images that capture attention and support your content.

URL Slug

The unique portion of the URL for this post. For example, in "yoursite.com/posts/my-first-post", "my-first-post" is the slug.

  • Use lowercase letters and hyphens
  • Keep it short but descriptive
  • Include relevant keywords when possible
  • Avoid special characters

Content

The main body of your post, supporting rich text formatting including:

  • Headings and subheadings
  • Paragraphs with formatting (bold, italic, etc.)
  • Links to other content
  • Bulleted and numbered lists
  • Images and media

Author

Select the team member who wrote the post. This helps:

  • Give credit to your writers
  • Build authority for your content
  • Allow readers to find more posts by the same author

Publishing Options

  • Draft: Work on the post privately
  • In Review: Submit for team review
  • Published: Make the post public
  • Schedule: Set a future publication date and time

Best Practices for Blog Posts

Writing Tips

  • Start with a strong opening paragraph
  • Use subheadings to break up long content
  • Keep paragraphs short (3-4 sentences)
  • Include relevant internal and external links
  • End with a clear conclusion or call to action

SEO Considerations

  • Include your main keyword in the title
  • Use descriptive alt text for images
  • Write naturally for your audience
  • Link to related content on your site
  • Use appropriate heading hierarchy

Image Guidelines

  • Choose relevant, high-quality featured images
  • Optimize images for web performance
  • Use consistent image sizes
  • Include descriptive alt text
  • Consider image placement within content
